briefdescription.para: Magic return values from general_work.

detaileddescription.para: Scheduler doesn't propagate tags from in- to output. The block itself is free to insert tags as it wants.
Propagate tags from all in- to all outputs. The scheduler takes care of that.
Propagate tags from n. input to n. output. Requires same number of in- and outputs
Like TPP_DONT, but signals the block it should implement application-specific forwarding behaviour.

briefdescription.para: enum to represent different tag propagation policies.

detaileddescription.para: Used by block's setters and work functions to make setting/resetting of parameters thread-safe.
Used by calling gr::thread::scoped_lock l(d_setlock);
Used by blocks to access the logger system.
PMT Symbol for "hey, we're done here"
PMT Symbol of the system port, pmt::mp("system")

Assume block computes y_i = f(x_i, x_i-1, x_i-2, x_i-3...) History is the number of x_i's that are examined to produce one y_i. This comes in handy for FIR filters, where we use history to ensure that our input contains the appropriate "history" for the filter. History should be equal to the number of filter taps. First history samples (when there are no previous samples) are initialized with zeroes.

Declares the block's delay in samples. Since the delay of blocks like filters is derived from the taps and not the block itself, we cannot automatically calculate this value and so leave it as a user-defined property. It defaults to 0 is not set.
This does not actively set the delay; it just tells the scheduler what the delay is.

This delay is mostly used to adjust the placement of the tags and is not currently used for any signal processing. When a tag is passed through a block with internal delay, its location should be moved based on the delay of the block. This interface allows us to tell the scheduler this value.

parameterdescription.para: The buffer on which to set the delay.
The sample delay of the data stream.

detaileddescription.para: Convenience wrapper to gr::block::declare_delay(int which, unsigned delay) to set all ports to the same delay.

Gets the delay of the block. Since the delay of blocks like filters is derived from the taps and not the block itself, we cannot automatically calculate this value and so leave it as a user-defined property. It defaults to 0 is not set.

parameterdescription.para: Which port from which to get the sample delay.

briefdescription.para: Return true if this block has a fixed input to output rate.

detaileddescription.para: If true, then fixed_rate_in_to_out and fixed_rate_out_to_in may be called.

briefdescription.para: Estimate input requirements given output request.

detaileddescription.para:
noutput_items
number of output items to produce
ninput_items_required
number of input items required on each input stream
Given a request to product noutput_items, estimate the number of data items required on each input stream. The estimate doesn't have to be exact, but should be close.

briefdescription.para: compute output items from input items

detaileddescription.para:
noutput_items
number of output items to write on each output stream
ninput_items
number of input items available on each input stream
input_items
vector of pointers to the input items, one entry per input stream
output_items
vector of pointers to the output items, one entry per output stream
number of items actually written to each output stream or WORK_CALLED_PRODUCE or WORK_DONE. It is OK to return a value less than noutput_items. WORK_CALLED_PRODUCE is used where not all outputs produce the same number of items. general_work must call produce() for each output to indicate the numer of items actually produced.
WORK_DONE indicates that no more data will be produced by this block.
general_work must call consume or consume_each to indicate how many items were consumed on each input stream.

briefdescription.para: Called to enable drivers, etc for i/o devices.

detaileddescription.para: This allows a block to enable an associated driver to begin transferring data just before we start to execute the scheduler. The end result is that this reduces latency in the pipeline when dealing with audio devices, usrps, etc.

briefdescription.para: Called to disable drivers, etc for i/o devices.
Constrain the noutput_items argument passed to forecast and general_work.

detaileddescription.para:
set_output_multiple causes the scheduler to ensure that the noutput_items argument passed to forecast and general_work will be an integer multiple of
multiple
The default value of output multiple is 1.

briefdescription.para: Constrains buffers to work on a set item alignment (for SIMD)

detaileddescription.para:
set_alignment_multiple causes the scheduler to ensure that the noutput_items argument passed to forecast and general_work will be an integer multiple of
multiple
The default value is 1.
This control is similar to the output_multiple setting, except that if the number of items passed to the block is less than the output_multiple, this value is ignored and the block can produce like normal. The d_unaligned value is set to the number of items the block is off by. In the next call to general_work, the noutput_items is set to d_unaligned or less until d_unaligned==0. The buffers are now aligned again and the aligned calls can be performed again.

briefdescription.para: Tell the scheduler how_many_items of input stream which_input were consumed.

detaileddescription.para: This function should be used in general_work() to tell the scheduler the number of input items processed. Calling consume() multiple times in the same general_work() call is safe. Every invocation of consume() updates the values returned by nitems_read().

briefdescription.para: Tell the scheduler how_many_items were consumed on each input stream.

detaileddescription.para: Also see notes on consume().

briefdescription.para: Tell the scheduler how_many_items were produced on output stream which_output.

detaileddescription.para: This function should be used in general_work() to tell the scheduler the number of output items produced. If produce() is called in general_work(), general_work() must return WORK_CALLED_PRODUCE. Calling produce() multiple times in the same general_work() call is safe. Every invocation of produce() updates the values returned by nitems_written().

briefdescription.para: Set the approximate output rate / input rate.

detaileddescription.para: Provide a hint to the buffer allocator and scheduler. The default relative_rate is 1.0
decimators have relative_rates < 1.0 interpolators have relative_rates > 1.0

briefdescription.para: return the approximate output rate / input rate
Given ninput samples, return number of output samples that will be produced. N.B. this is only defined if fixed_rate returns true. Generally speaking, you don't need to override this.
Given noutput samples, return number of input samples required to produce noutput. N.B. this is only defined if fixed_rate returns true. Generally speaking, you don't need to override this.
Return the number of items read on input stream which_input.
Return the number of items written on output stream which_output.
Asks for the policy used by the scheduler to moved tags downstream.
Set the policy by the scheduler to determine how tags are moved downstream.
Return the minimum number of output items this block can produce during a call to work.

detaileddescription.para: Should be 0 for most blocks. Useful if we're dealing with packets and the block produces one packet per call to work.

briefdescription.para: Set the minimum number of output items this block can produce during a call to work.

parameterdescription.para: the minimum noutput_items this block can produce.

briefdescription.para: Return the maximum number of output items this block will handle during a call to work.
Set the maximum number of output items this block will handle during a call to work.

parameterdescription.para: the maximum noutput_items this block will handle.

briefdescription.para: Clear the switch for using the max_noutput_items value of this block.

detaileddescription.para: When is_set_max_noutput_items() returns 'true', the scheduler will use the value returned by max_noutput_items() to limit the size of the number of items possible for this block's work function. If is_set_max_notput_items() returns 'false', then the scheduler ignores the internal value and uses the value set globally in the top_block.

Use this value to clear the 'is_set' flag so the scheduler will ignore this. Use the set_max_noutput_items(m) call to both set a new value for max_noutput_items and to re-enable its use in the scheduler.

briefdescription.para: Ask the block if the flag is or is not set to use the internal value of max_noutput_items during a call to work.
Returns max buffer size on output port i.
Request limit on max buffer size on all output ports.

detaileddescription.para: This is an advanced feature. Calling this can affect some fundamental assumptions about the system behavior and performance.

The actual buffer size is determined by a number of other factors from the block and system. This function only provides a requested maximum. The buffers will always be a multiple of the system page size, which may be larger than the value asked for here.

parameterdescription.para: the requested maximum output size in items.

briefdescription.para: Request limit on max buffer size on output port port.

detaileddescription.para: This is an advanced feature. Calling this can affect some fundamental assumptions about the system behavior and performance.

The actual buffer size is determined by a number of other factors from the block and system. This function only provides a requested maximum. The buffers will always be a multiple of the system page size, which may be larger than the value asked for here.

parameterdescription.para: the output port the request applies to.
the requested maximum output size in items.

briefdescription.para: Returns min buffer size on output port i.
Request limit on the minimum buffer size on all output ports.

detaileddescription.para: This is an advanced feature. Calling this can affect some fundamental assumptions about the system behavior and performance.

The actual buffer size is determined by a number of other factors from the block and system. This function only provides a requested minimum. The buffers will always be a multiple of the system page size, which may be larger than the value asked for here.

parameterdescription.para: the requested minimum output size in items.

briefdescription.para: Request limit on min buffer size on output port port.

detaileddescription.para: This is an advanced feature. Calling this can affect some fundamental assumptions about the system behavior and performance.

The actual buffer size is determined by a number of other factors from the block and system. This function only provides a requested minimum. The buffers will always be a multiple of the system page size, which may be larger than the value asked for here.

parameterdescription.para: the output port the request applies to.
the requested minimum output size in items.

briefdescription.para: Gets instantaneous noutput_items performance counter.
Gets average noutput_items performance counter.
Gets variance of noutput_items performance counter.
Gets instantaneous num items produced performance counter.
Gets average num items produced performance counter.
Gets variance of num items produced performance counter.
Gets instantaneous fullness of which input buffer.
Gets average fullness of which input buffer.
Gets variance of fullness of which input buffer.
Gets instantaneous fullness of all input buffers.
Gets average fullness of all input buffers.
Gets variance of fullness of all input buffers.
Gets instantaneous fullness of which input buffer.
Gets average fullness of which input buffer.
Gets variance of fullness of which input buffer.
Gets instantaneous fullness of all output buffers.
Gets average fullness of all output buffers.
Gets variance of fullness of all output buffers.
Gets instantaneous clock cycles spent in work.
Gets average clock cycles spent in work.
Gets average clock cycles spent in work.
Gets total clock cycles spent in work.
Gets average throughput.
Resets the performance counters.
Sets up export of perf. counters to ControlPort. Only called by the scheduler.
Checks if this block is already exporting perf. counters to ControlPort.
If the block calls this in its constructor, it's perf. counters will not be exported.
Set the thread's affinity to processor core n.

parameterdescription.para: a vector of ints of the core numbers available to this block.

briefdescription.para: Remove processor affinity to a specific core.
Get the current processor affinity.
Get the current thread priority in use.
Get the current thread priority stored.
Set the current thread priority.
the system message handler
returns true when execution has completed due to a message connection
Tell msg neighbors we are finished.
Make sure we don't think we are finished.

memberdef.argsstring: (std::vector< tag_t > &v, unsigned int which_input, uint64_t abs_start, uint64_t abs_end)
memberdef.name: get_tags_in_range

briefdescription.para: Given a [start,end), returns a vector of all tags in the range.

detaileddescription.para: Range of counts is from start to end-1.
Tags are tuples of: (item count, source id, key, value)

parameterdescription.para: a vector reference to return tags into
an integer of which input stream to pull from
a uint64 count of the start of the range of interest
a uint64 count of the end of the range of interest

memberdef.name: get_tags_in_window

briefdescription.para: Gets all tags within the relative window of the current call to work.

detaileddescription.para: This opperates much like get_tags_in_range but allows us to work within the current window of items. Item range is therefore within the possible range of 0 to ninput_items[whic_input].
Range of items counts from rel_start to rel_end-1 within current window.
Tags are tuples of: (item count, source id, key, value)

parameterdescription.para: a vector reference to return tags into
an integer of which input stream to pull from
a uint64 count of the start of the range of interest
a uint64 count of the end of the range of interest

an integer of which input stream to pull from
a uint64 count of the start of the range of interest
a uint64 count of the end of the range of interest
a PMT symbol key to filter only tags of this key

briefdescription.para: The abstract base class for all 'terminal' processing blocks.

A signal processing flow is constructed by creating a tree of hierarchical blocks, which at any level may also contain terminal nodes that actually implement signal processing functions. This is the base class for all such leaf nodes.

detaileddescription.para: Blocks have a set of input streams and output streams. The input_signature and output_signature define the number of input streams and output streams respectively, and the type of the data items in each stream.
Blocks report the number of items consumed on each input in general_work(), using consume() or consume_each().

If the same number of items is produced on each output, the block returns that number from general_work(). Otherwise, the block calls produce() for each output, then returns WORK_CALLED_PRODUCE. The input and output rates are not required to be related.

User derived blocks override two methods, forecast and general_work, to implement their signal processing behavior. forecast is called by the system scheduler to determine how many items are required on each input stream in order to produce a given number of output items.
general_work is called to perform the signal processing in the block. It reads the input items and writes the output items.
